metadata.case_name: State of Punjab v. Khan Chand

facts.text: Respondent Khan Chand is owner of Tata Mercedes Benz truck No. 1607.

On December 18, 1964, District Magistrate Rohtak passed order under section 2 of East Punjab Movable Property (Requisitioning) Act, 1947 requiring respondent to place truck at disposal of Executive Engineer Rohtak for carrying road material for famine work; compensation at government rate mentioned.
Truck taken into possession by District Magistrate on December 19, 1964.
Respondent filed petition under Article 226 in Punjab High Court challenging District Magistrate's order and constitutionality of the Act.
Petition resisted by State of Punjab and District Magistrate Rohtak; affidavit of District Magistrate filed.
Single Judge referred to Division Bench; Division Bench referred to Full Bench due to importance.
Punjab High Court Full Bench judgment dated March 24, 1966 in C.W. No. 26 of 1965 struck down section 2 as violative of Article 14; held entire Act unconstitutional as section 2 not severable.
Act replaced Ordinance V of 1947 promulgated September 15, 1947; published December 13, 1947; pre-Constitution law.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 2 of the East Punjab Movable Property (Requisitioning) Act, 1947 violates Article 14 of the Constitution.
Whether section 2 is severable from the rest of the Act, or if the entire Act is unconstitutional.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of section 2 do not contravene Article 14; vesting of discretion does not entail contravention if guidelines exist; Act provides policy via preamble for requisitioning and acquisition of movable property.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar; Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India; Harishankar Bagla v. State of MP; Sri Ram Ram Narain Medhi v. State of Bombay; P.J. Irani v. State of Madras

petitioner_arguments.text: Pre-Constitution law protected under Article 31(5) from certain challenges; distinction between discretion on fundamental rights and other rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 31(5); Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: Section 2 gives unfettered and unguided power to executive to interfere with property rights arbitrarily; no principle or policy for guidance; violates Article 14.

court_reasoning.text: Section 2 confers uncontrolled power on State Government or delegated officers to requisition any movable property without guidelines on purpose, public purpose requirement, emergency, or compensation principles; arbitrary and discriminatory; violates Article 14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Total absence of guidelines vitiates section 2; power can degenerate into arbitrariness.

court_reasoning.text: Section 3 cannot come into operation without section 2; other provisions ancillary; entire Act unconstitutional as section 2 not severable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrimination writ large on face of Act.

court_reasoning.text: Pre-Constitution laws not immune from Article 14 challenge per Article 31(5); cannot read 'public purpose' into section 2.
Dissent (Mathew J.): Implied public purpose; 'necessary or expedient' provides guidance; presumption of proper exercise by high officials; delegation valid; requisition for famine work reasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power capable of reasonable administration; strike down abuse, not law.

holdings.text: Section 2 of East Punjab Movable Property (Requisitioning) Act, 1947 violates Article 14; entire Act unconstitutional and void.
Appeals fail as High Court judgment sustained.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S.R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Court examines if statute lays down principle/policy for discretion; strikes down if arbitrary power to discriminate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between discretion on fundamental rights vs. others; Article 14 invoked only if real discrimination and impinges fundamental right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature laid down policy in Essential Supplies Act; no such policy here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Ram Ram Narain Medhi v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Preamble and sections laid down policy; not here.

precedents_cited.case_name: P.J. Irani v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Preamble and provisions provided guidance; not here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jayantilal Parshottamdas v. State of Gujarat
precedents_cited.relevance: Sustained where purpose specified; no purpose here.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Movable Property (Requisitioning) Act, 1947 (East Punjab Act XV of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Section 2 held violative of Article 14 for lack of guidelines; entire Act unconstitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Article 14 violated by arbitrary power; Article 31(5) no immunity from Article 14 challenge.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Expressly requires public purpose; contrasted with impugned Act.

statutes_cited.name: Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1952

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeals filed by State of Punjab, upholding Punjab High Court Full Bench judgment striking down entire East Punjab Movable Property (Requisitioning) Act, 1947 as unconstitutional under Article 14.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of Act unconstitutional; writ petition of respondent upheld.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs. One set of hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: Arbitrariness and the power to discriminate are writ large on the face of the said provision of the Act and, in our opinion, that provision falls within the mischief which article 14 of the Constitution is designed to prevent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on violation of Article 14 by section 2.

key_quotes.text: It is the absence of any principle or policy for the guidance of the authority concerned in the exercise of discretion which vitiates an enactment and makes it vulnerable to the attack on the ground of violation of article 14.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why unguided discretion invalidates law.

key_quotes.text: Nobody could or would, in the year of our Lord 1973, read the section in any other manner [as implying public purpose].
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissenting view implying public purpose in section 2.
